LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka 
   
Classification   Targeting classification: General intervention 
  Sector (subsector): Transport, and information and

Themes (subthemes): Economic growth (widening access to

Project Description  The  Eastern  and  North  Central  Provincial  Road  Project  (the 
Project) will rehabilitate about 370 kilometers (km) of provincial 
roads in Eastern Province and North Central Province (NCP). 
Pavement  will  be  strengthened,  and  bridges,  drainage,  and 
culverts will be improved or replaced as necessary. Consulting 
services  will  be  provided  to  support  project  implementation, 
strengthening the project management capability of the Eastern 
Provincial Road Development Department (EPRDD) and North 
Central Provincial Road Development Authority (NCPRDA). 
 
Overall road sector management capacity in both provinces will 
be  enhanced  by  (i)  modernizing  the  EPRDD  office,  and  (ii) 
improving the capacity of EPRDD and NCPRDA to manage road 
assets. 
   
Rationale  Those who live in eastern Sri Lanka have especially suffered 
from the consequences of the country’s prolonged conflict. With 
the  holding  of  elections  in  the  Eastern  Province,  and  the 
constitution  of  the  Provincial  Council,  the  Government  of  Sri 
Lanka has focused on Eastern Province's development (and that 
of  adjacent  provinces)  within  the  framework  of  devolution 
introduced  by  the  13th  amendment  to  the  Constitution.  The 
Project  will  support  the  Government's  objective  by  improving 
provincial roads  and strengthening and enhancing capacity of 
devolved  structures  of  provincial  road  institutions  in  Eastern 
Province and adjacent NCP. 
 
The Project will improve connectivity in the provinces’ transport 
networks. Improved roads—in conjunction with a range of other 
carefully  coordinated  measures  proposed  in  the  country 
partnership  strategy  (CPS)  and  designed  to  strengthen 
administrative and absorptive capacity in poorer regions—will 
contribute  to  poverty  reduction.  By  improving  connectivity  to 
neglected  areas,  the  Project  will  support  socially  inclusive 
development. Therefore, because it will contribute to reducing

ii   
disparities in Sri Lanka, the Project is in line with the CPS. 
The institutional capacities of EPRDD and NCPRDA must be 
strengthened,  particularly  in  planning,  programming,  and 
contract  administration.  The  Project  will  also  help  strengthen 
their institutional capacity in road asset management. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The  impact  will  be  an  overall  improvement  of  Sri  Lanka’s 
transport  system.  Transport  of  goods  and  services  will  be 
enhanced, contributing to economic growth and community well 
being. The Project's immediate outcome will be an improved 
road network and institutional capacity in Eastern Province and 
NCP. 
   
Project Investment Plan   The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $78.0 million, 
including taxes and duties of $8.0 million and interest during 
construction of $2.8 million.  
   
Financing Plan  The  financing  plan  includes  a  loan  in  various  currencies 
equivalent  to  SDR45,320,000  ($70  million  equivalent)  from 
Special Funds resources of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
The loan will have a 32-year term, including an 8-year grace 
period, an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per year during the 
grace period and 1.5% per year thereafter, and such other terms 
and conditions as are set forth in the draft loan and project 
agreements. 
   
Period of Utilization  Until 30 June 2014 
   
Estimated Project  31 December 2013 
Completion Date

Implementing Agencies  Eastern Provincial Council through EPRDD 
North Central Provincial Council through NCPRDA 
   
Implementation  MLGPC, through the existing project coordinating unit that is 
Arrangements  responsible for coordinating project preparatory activities for all 
provincial roads, will be responsible for overall coordination of 
the Project, including provision of policy and technical guidance 
and  interagency  coordination.  For  procurement  and  project 
implementation,  EPRDD  and  NCPRDA,  led  by  a  provincial 
director and general manager, respectively, will be responsible 
for  day-to-day  implementation.  The  provincial  director  and 
general manager have been delegated adequate technical and 
administrative authority for expeditious project implementation. 
Assisted by MLGPC, EPRDD and NCPRDA will engage project 
implementation consultants separately to act as engineers for 
the civil works contracts.

iii
 
Procurement  Procurement under the loan will be carried out in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from 
time  to  time)  and  the  Government's  tender  procedures 
acceptable  to  ADB.  Supply  contracts  will  be  procured  under 
national competitive bidding procedures if the contract values 
are $100,000–$1,000,000, and shopping if less than $100,000. 
As requested by the Government, national competitive bidding 
procedures acceptable to ADB will be adopted for civil works. 
There will be 22 road, 4 bridge, and 2 building works contract 
packages, ranging between $0.2 million and $3.4 million. 
   
Consulting Services  Consultants  will  be  recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time). For each province, an international consulting firm 
in association with national consulting firm(s) will be hired as 
project implementation consultants, which will assume the role 
of  the  engineer  for  the  civil  works  contracts.  In  total,  about 
70  person-months  of  international  consultants  and 
1,514 person-months of national consultants will be required.  
   
Project Benefits and  The Project will contribute to the improvement of the overall 
Beneficiaries  performance of road sector in Eastern Province and NCP by 
improving  transport  efficiency  and  expanding  access  to 
economic opportunities and public services. The beneficiaries 
will  be  people,  companies,  government  agencies,  and 
nongovernment  agencies  that  use  project  road  transport 
services  directly  and  indirectly.  Communities  served  by  the 
project roads will benefit from improved, lower-cost, and faster 
transport  services,  and  thereby  obtain  improved  access  to 
economic opportunities and social services. The benefits are not 
confined  to  any  specific  ethnic  or  other  social  group.  The 
improved roads will facilitate movement of goods and people, 
and improve livelihood activities of the communities along the 
roads, including returned internally displaced people. The local 
labor force will have access to employment opportunities during 
the construction phase and maintenance. Transport operators, 
carrying both passengers and freight, will benefit from improved 
roads in terms of lower vehicle-operating costs, time-savings, 
and  improved  road  safety,  thereby  increased  productivity. 
Government and nongovernment agencies served by the project 
roads  will  improve  their  service  delivery  due  to  improved 
transport efficiency. 
 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The risk of initial delays has been mitigated through ensuring 
project implementation readiness during processing. A feasibility 
study,  detailed  design  and  procurement  assistance  were 
provided through the ongoing technical assistance loan for the 
Road Project Preparatory Facility. Advance actions are being 
taken  with  the  objective  of  awarding  about  50  percent  of

iv   
contracts immediately following loan effectiveness. The risk of 
delay  in  releasing  counterpart  funds  has  been  mitigated  by 
providing  90%  of  financing  under  the  loan,  leaving  the 
Government to finance only tax and duties.  
 
Performance-based  maintenance  after  completion  will  be 
included in the civil works contracts. The EPRDD and NCPRDA 
road asset management systems will be strengthened for better 
planning and budgeting. Maintenance budgets will be increased 
to  meet  requirements,  and  EPRDD  and  NCPRDA's  strict 
monitoring systems for implementation will minimize the risk of 
underutilizing  these  budgets.  The  Eastern  and  North  Central 
Provincial Councils have agreed to dedicate their vehicle license 
fee revenues to routine road maintenance. At least 70% of the 
required funds for periodic road maintenance will be provided by 
2012, with gradual increases of 10% every year. 
 
There are general risks associated with communal tension and 
sensitivities,  history,  political  uncertainty,  return  of  displaced 
persons, and considerable security staff presence. Such conflict-
sensitive considerations, including distribution fairness among 
different ethnic groups, were taken into account when selecting 
the roads and agreed upon by the Government and the Eastern 
and  North  Central  provincial  councils.  In  line  with  the  key 
operational  guidelines  provided  in  the  CPS  on  working  in 
conflict-affected  areas,  the  Project  has  been  prepared 
emphasizing  transparency  and  involving  stakeholders  and 
beneficiaries.   
   
Technical Assistance  In  conjunction  with  the  Project,  capacity-building  technical 
assistance (TA) will be provided for institutional development of 
provincial road agencies in Eastern Province and NCP to (i) 
modernize the offices, (ii) improve business processes, and (iii) 
manage road assets, strengthening their ability to support the 
devolution  process  under  the  13th  amendment  of  the 
Constitution. The TA is estimated to cost $950,000, of which 
ADB will finance $800,000 on a grant basis from its TA funding 
program. Consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB's 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time  to  time).  International  consulting  inputs  of  22  person-
months, and 14 person-months of national consulting inputs, will 
be required. The TA will be implemented from March 2010 to 
February 2012.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the Eastern and North Central Provincial 
Road Project (the Project). The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for 
Capacity Development of Provincial Road Agencies, and if the Board approves the proposed 
loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  Since 1983, Sri Lanka has suffered from prolonged conflict, and its population in the east 
has particularly suffered from its consequences. In October 2006, administration of Eastern 
Province  separated  from  the  combined  North-East  Provincial  Council.  An  elected  civil 
administration  was  then  established  in  2008,  when  the  Government  of  Sri  Lanka  took 
administrative control over Eastern Province. To catch up with developments in other parts of 
the country, the Government has been focusing on the development of Eastern Province and its 
adjacent provinces. It plans to redevelop and integrate the province into the wider economy. 
The Project will support the Government's objective by improving provincial roads in Eastern 
Province  and  adjacent  North  Central  Province  (NCP).  The  project  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. Details of the provincial road analysis are in Appendix 2.  
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
3.   Sri Lanka has a road network of about 116,000 kilometers (km), comprising about 
11,700 km of national highways (classes A and B); 15,500 km of provincial roads (classes C 
and D); 65,000 km of local authority roads (class E); and the remainder being unclassified 
roads.1 Road transport accounts for 90% of passenger and 95% of freight land transport. 
Vehicle ownership and road traffic continue to grow rapidly. 
 
4.  While the road network is extensive (1.6 km per square kilometer [km2]), most roads 
were built more than 60 years ago. Standards are inadequate to keep up with the growing 
passenger and freight traffic. Moreover, due to neglect of road maintenance, road conditions are 
often  poor.  It  is  estimated  that  the  percentages  of  the  national  and  provincial  roads  in 
maintainable condition are only 60% and 40%, respectively. 
 
5.  There are several agencies involved in the management of road infrastructure. The 
Ministry  of  Highways  and  Road  Development  has  overall  responsibility  for  policies  and 
programs  concerning  national  roads.  The  Road  Development  Authority  is  responsible  for 
planning and managing the development and maintenance of national roads. Following the 
passage of the 13th Amendment to the Constitution in 1987, responsibility for provincial roads 
was devolved to provincial councils. The Ministry of Local Government and Provincial Councils 
(MLGPC) is the provincial councils' representative in the Cabinet, responsible for national-level 
policy and legislation. Within provinces, provincial road agencies are responsible for planning 
and  managing  the  development  and  maintenance  of  provincial  roads.  Several  different 
structures were adopted for these agencies, including creating a separate road department

under the provincial council, assigning responsibilities to provincial engineering or public works 
departments, and establishing a separate road development authority.  
 
6.  In late 2005, supported by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and World Bank, the 
Road  Maintenance  Trust  Fund  was  established  to  finance  routine  and  periodic  road 
maintenance. Since 80% of traffic volume is on national roads in Sri Lanka, however, funds 
have been mainly allocated for national roads. Currently, with World Bank assistance, the fund’s 
effectiveness is being reviewed. Yet the need for provincial road maintenance remains urgent—
and as the responsibility to maintain provincial roads is with provincial councils, there is a need 
to find a mechanism for financing provincial road maintenance at the provincial level. ADB and 
the World Bank have conducted coordinated policy dialogues on this matter. 
 
1.  Eastern Province 
7.  The province consists of three districts: Ampara, Batticaloa, and Trincomalee. Nearly 
one third of its boundary is the eastern sea coast of Sri Lanka. Trincomalee has a natural  
deep-water harbor, the fifth largest in the world. Beaches were popular with tourists; however, 
over  the  past  two  decades,  they  have  also  witnessed  many  intermittent  armed  conflicts. 
Trincomalee is not developed other than for flour processing, cement manufacture, and oil 
storage facilities. The province’s economy is focused on agriculture, animal husbandry, and 
fisheries. 
 
8.  Its population is estimated at 1.46 million, made up of 40.3% Sri Lankan Tamil, 37.6% 
Sri Lankan Moor, and 21.6% Sinhalese.2 Due to the conflict, Eastern Province was not included 
in the last poverty study. However, it is understood that its poverty is among the worst in the 
country. Per capita income in 2007 was SLRs119,131 per year, or 66.6% of the national level. 
While  the  area  represents  15%  of  the  country,  its  gross  domestic  product  in  2007  was 
SLRs177,863, or 4.97% of the national gross domestic product. 
 
9.  The road network includes 857 km of national highways, 1,098 km of provincial roads 
(classes C and D), 4,838 km of rural roads (class E), and 3,412 km of other roads. The road 
density is 1.02 km per km2, while the national road density is 1.60 km per km2. Most of its roads 
were severely damaged and neglected during the conflict. About 30% of provincial roads are 
gravel and earth roads. Only 20% are in good condition. Where access is possible, riding 
conditions are poor, vehicle speeds are low, and vehicle-operating costs are high.  
10.  The Eastern Provincial Road Development Department (EPRDD) is responsible for the 
construction, maintenance, and administration of the provincial road network. It is headed by a 
provincial director who works directly under the authority of the province’s Secretary of road 
development. Key personnel under the provincial director include a deputy director, four chief 
engineers, a chief accountant, an administrative officer, and other support staff. Three chief 
engineers are responsible for monitoring the works executed by respective executive engineers. 
One chief engineer is responsible for planning, design, and quality control. A special unit for 
machinery and equipment is kept for deployment within the province. 
11.  Some  EPRDD  staff  members  were  involved  in  ADB-financed  projects,  including 
provincial and rural road components of the ADB-funded Conflict-Affected Areas Rehabilitation 
Project, Tsunami-Affected Areas Rebuilding Project, and North East Community Restoration

funded Pro-Poor Eastern Infrastructure Development Project.4 
 
12.  In 2007, the estimated fleet of motorized vehicles in Eastern Province was 92,091, or 
around 4.1% of the national fleet. Motorcycles make up almost 70% of the fleet. In 2007, 
Eastern Province developed procedures for collecting revenue from vehicle license fees. For the 
period January–November 2008, this revenue was almost SLRs100 million. 
 
13.  Budgetary  expenditure  for  provincial  roads  is  funded  by  the  Government,  and  has 
steadily increased: SLRs159.0 million in 2006, SLRs193.1 million in 2007, and SLRs215.0 
million in 2008. The actual expenditures, however, were only SLRs97.1 million, SLRs105.2 
million, and SLRs70.3 million, respectively, due to unreleased funds. 
 
14.  There are around 130 interprovincial bus services per day, and 500 buses are operating 
within the province—the lowest bus penetration in the country. There are 47 dedicated rural bus 
services that are subsidized, providing important connections between rural and town centers. 
Two-wheelers and hand tractors are also used extensively, as are small trucks and vans. 
Trucking is deregulated, and rates are competitive. 
 
2.  North Central Province 
15.  NCP has two administrative districts, Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa, named after their 
respective capital cities. Anuradhapura was the capital of Sri Lanka from the 4th century BC 
until the beginning of the 11th century AD. The capital then moved east to Polonnaruwa, where 
it stood until the end of the 13th century AD. The ruins of the cities have been designated as 
cultural heritage sites and are immensely popular with tourists. 
 
16.  The province is considered poor and is sparsely populated, as the land tends to be dry 
tropical woodland. Having more than 10,000 water reservoirs, irrigated paddy fields are the 
largest employment provider. The area presently contributes over 20% of the country's paddy 
production, in addition to vegetables and animal husbandry. Its share of the national gross 
domestic product is around 4%, and it had a 2007 per capita income of SLRs117,384, which 
was 65.7% of the national level and one of the lowest gross domestic product growth rates in 
the country. The province is home to about 1.1 million people, of whom 17.5% exist below the 
poverty line as compared to 15.0% nationally. 
 
17.  The road network includes 1,141 km of national highways, about 1,951 km of provincial 
roads, 11,835 km of rural roads, and 1,173 km of other roads. Road density is 0.84 km per km2, 
far below of the national average of 1.60 km per km2. About 22% of the provincial roads require 
reconstruction, 18% require rehabilitation, while 38% and 22% are in fair and good conditions, 
respectively. More than 37% are gravel or earth roads. From 2003 to 2007, the vehicle fleet 
increased  at  an  average  annual  growth  rate  of  16.6%,  most  due  to  motorcycles  and  
three-wheelers.

18.  Responsibility  for  managing  provincial  roads  in  NCP  lies  with  the  North  Central 
Provincial Road Development Authority (NCPRDA), which is headed by a board of directors, 
one of whom is appointed as the chairperson. The next in line is the general manager, who is 
responsible for the execution of NCPRDA’s work program and administration. There are two 
deputy general managers for engineering and for financial and human resources development. 
The deputy general manager (engineering) manages roadwork with the assistance of the three 
chief engineers. Out of these three, two are handle operations in the two districts. The other 
chief engineer (planning, design, and quality control) is supported by another four executive 
engineers for planning, design, and quality control. All maintenance and improvement work is 
contracted to private contractors. NCPRDA does not operate specific machinery but maintains a 
fairly good laboratory for quality control.   
 
19.  Capacity  building  was  provided  to  NCPRDA  through  the  ADB-funded  Road  Sector 
Development  Project5 (RSDP).  A  software  program  for  maintaining  a  road  inventory  and 
condition database for provincial road networks was in place. However, road rehabilitation and 
maintenance have not been conducted regularly due to the inconsistency and inadequacy of 
available funds. Most are still handled on an ad-hoc basis. 
 
20.  Budgetary  expenditures  for  provincial  roads  are  funded  by  the  Government,  which 
totaled SLRs365 million in 2006, SLRs425 million in 2007, and SLRs325 million in 2008. On 
average, actual expenditures are about 70% of the allocations. The low utilization is mostly due 
to unreleased allocations or delayed release during the later part of the year, making it difficult 
to complete all planned work programs. 
 
21.  The Department of Motor Traffic collects revenue from vehicle registration within the 
province. Revenues related to road use are mainly from these fees, which were about SLRs90.0 
million in 2006, SLRs118.0 million in 2007, and SLRs120.8 million in 2008. The relatively high 
increase in 2007 was due to improvement of vehicle registration system and an increase in 
fees.  
 
22.  The Road Passenger Transport Authority is responsible for regularizing the provision of 
omnibus transport and is authorized to issue route permits for intraprovincial buses. There are 
about 652 private omnibuses and 262 state-owned buses. Other passenger vehicles include 
school vans, office vans, two-wheelers, and three-wheelers or taxis. Trucking is deregulated 
with competitive rates. Railways also provide services, but mostly for the transport of fuel and 
cement. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
23.  In Sri Lanka, high poverty levels are linked to lack of access to infrastructure; similarly, 
poor infrastructure constrains growth. Rural enterprises cite transport as a major obstacle to 
starting or operating a business. Provincial roads provide essential connectivity, linking national 
roads,  which  connect  consumer  areas,  and  local  roads,  which  connect  rural  agricultural 
production areas. Provincial roads also facilitate essential bus services, ensuring access to 
economic opportunities and inclusive growth. In Eastern Province and NCP, therefore, improved 
provincial roads and resulting benefits will help balance socioeconomic disparities within the 
provinces and keep up with national-level economic growth.

1.  Decentralization of Provincial Road Management 
 
24.  In accordance with the 13th Amendment to the Constitution, responsibility for managing 
the development and maintenance of provincial roads lies with provincial councils.6 However, 
technical capabilities, training facilities, knowledge bases of codes and practices, and databases 
are still retained at the central Government level. As a result, provincial-level capacity has 
lagged, especially in the newly established Provincial Council in Eastern Province.   
 
25.  ADB and JICA have assisted some provincial road agencies with capacity building in 
planning,  budgeting,  and  contract  management.  Therefore,  NCPRDA's  capacity  is  more 
advanced than that of EPRDD. Below are analyses of agencies’ capacity in performing their 
mandates to manage provincial road networks, including (i) planning and programming, (ii) 
project  preparation,  (iii)  procurement  and  contract  management,  and  (iv)  monitoring  and 
evaluation of program implementation. 
 
26.  Planning and Programming. Provincial road agencies are to develop and maintain a 
road inventory and condition database—a prerequisite for preparing annual or rolling road 
rehabilitation and maintenance programs along with associated budgets.   
 
27.  In  NCP,  inventory,  road  condition  database,  and  road  maintenance  management 
systems are in place, and have been used to prepare road maintenance budgets for 2007 
onward. Implementation of plans, however, has been constrained by a lack of funds. To ensure 
sustainability,  the  road  maintenance  management  system  needs  to  be  updated,  a  
3-year rolling plan developed, and more stable financing secured. 
 
28.  In Eastern Province, while the existing structure is reasonably sound from an operational 
perspective,  it  does  not  have  the  planning  capacity  to  fulfill  EPRDD's  mandate.  Although 
EPRDD has an inventory in place, no systematic road condition assessments are carried out for 
use in the budget estimating process. Budgets are estimated based on a generalized scope of 
work for important roads only as well as some indicative work for a certain number of km up to 
the anticipated maximum amount of money approved from historical allocation. 
 
29.  Project Preparation. Based on the work program and approved budget, provincial road 
agencies  are  to  identify  and  formulate  projects,  and  prepare  detailed  design  and  bidding 
documents. Both agencies have the capacity to prepare domestically funded projects, mainly for 
maintenance. For road rehabilitation and reconstruction projects (mostly foreign-funded), project 
preparatory  work—including  feasibility  studies,  detailed  design,  bidding  documents,  and 
procurement actions—are carried out with the significant involvement of the Government (i.e., 
MLGPC). However, under the Project, in line with the devolution process, the agencies have 
been involved throughout the preparation period.  
 
30.  Procurement  and  Contract  Management.  Both  agencies  are  experienced  in 
procurement and contract management of domestically funded projects. For externally funded 
projects, MLGPC has extensive experience in both procurement and contract management.  
 
31.  Under  the  Project,  all  civil  works  contracts  have  been  procured  using  national 
competitive bidding procedures and packaged to promote provincial-level procurement and

2.  Road Financing 
34.  There is a serious imbalance between the decentralization of expenditures and revenues 
at the provincial level. The devolution design did not envision any significant revenue sharing, 
and with limited assigned revenues, vertical imbalances have been addressed solely by a 
system of provincial grants from the central Government.  
 
35.  Currently, of the total financial needs for both recurrent and capital expenditures, the 
Government allocates more than 90% of all provincial council budgetary needs, with provincial 
revenue  accounting  for  only  10%  (i.e.,  devolved  revenues).  Of  total  provincial  revenues,  
20%–25% is earned from the vehicle license fees. Provincial councils do not have specific 
guidelines for allocating funds to the road sector. 
 
36.  In general, road sector expenditures are funded from central Government funds, foreign 
or external funds, and provincial revenues. While rehabilitation of provincial roads has relied 
heavily on foreign-funded projects, the existing level of domestic funding is insufficient for 
provincial road agencies to maintain their road networks. There is a need to increase the level of 
road budgets and to assign a greater amount to road maintenance based on road conditions. 
Proper  planning  needs  to  be  developed,  and  the  Government's  commitment  to  provide 
adequate financing for maintenance needs to be secured.  
 
37.  Under the Project, Eastern Province and NCP agreed to dedicate their vehicle license 
fee revenues to road maintenance, which will be sufficient to finance routine maintenance and a 
portion of periodic maintenance. Funds will be disbursed in such a way to meet the stable 
network needs to avoid further deterioration of the network. To increase quality of construction 
and efficiency of maintenance work, performance-based road rehabilitation and maintenance 
contracts will be introduced under the Project.  
 
38.  To secure periodic maintenance financing for provincial roads, the Government and both 
provinces agreed that at least 70% of required funds for periodic maintenance of provincial 
roads will be provided to the provincial councils by 2012, with a yearly increase of 10% until 
100% of the requirement is reached.

3.  Past and Proposed Institutional Capacity Program 
39.  Under the ADB-funded Southern Provincial Roads Improvement Project7 (SPRIP), an 
institutional development program was implemented in Southern Province to establish capacity 
for efficient and effective management of its provincial road network. The SPRIP reorganized 
the Southern Provincial Road Development Authority by (i) formulating more efficient work 
procedures, and (ii) introducing appropriate modern road management tools and information 
and communication technologies. Due to its success, the same approach had been replicated in 
four more provinces (North Central, North Western, Uva, and Western) through the RSDP, and 
in  two  other  provinces  (Central  and  Sabaraghamuwa)  through  the  JICA-funded  Provincial 
Roads  Improvement  Project.  The  progress,  achievement,  and  lessons  of  the  institutional 
development program under both projects were assessed as summarized in Supplementary 
Appendix A.  
 
40.  While  the  institutional  development  program  under  the  SPRIP  was  considered 
successful, the same under the RSDP was considered only a moderate success. The success 
of the former was due to the program being dedicated to a single provincial road agency and the 
consulting team being based at that office, providing hands-on training for day-to-day road 
network  management  as  well  as  project  management.  Under  the  latter  project,  a  generic 
program  that  targeted  all  provinces  has  not  necessarily  delivered  the  desired  outcomes. 
Moreover, as the main consultant is based in Colombo at the MLGPC, the consultant had much 
less  direct  interaction  with  the  four  provincial  road  agencies,  resulting  in  less  effective 
assistance.   
 
41.  To  support  the  devolution  process,  the  Project  will  continue  to  support  capacity 
development of provincial road agencies in Eastern Province and NCP through TA, taking into 
consideration the different stages of development and capacity of each. With regard to project 
management capacity, two separate consulting teams for project implementation located in 
each province will provide hands-on training to each agency. There will be no separate project 
management  unit  for  the  Project,  but  its  functions  will  be  internalized  in  the  agency’s 
organizational structures, so that skills can be retained.

5.  Lessons Learned 
44.  ADB's  country  assistance  program  evaluation  in  20079 states  that  given  budgetary 
constraints,  the  demand  for  government  counterpart  funds  for  externally  funded  projects 
competes with and crowds out maintenance funds. The overall balance among maintenance 
and rehabilitation is sometimes overlooked. Another risk is the inadequate institutional capacity 
for maintenance of roads by local authorities. These risks are manageable and can be mitigated 
with measures to strengthen capacity and funding for maintenance. 
 
45.  This evaluation also identified key challenges relevant to the Project, including the risk of 
project implementation in conflict-affected areas. As suggested, a conflict risk assessment and 
its  effects  on  project  implementation  have  been  carried  out.  In  accordance  with  its 
recommendations, the roads to be improved are spread throughout the provinces and reach all 
communities. Selection of roads has been agreed with the Eastern Provincial Council and North 
Central Provincial Council. Civil works have been packaged within a wide range of national 
contractor capacities. Moreover, since the Project will rehabilitate existing roads, the prospect of 
land acquisition has been minimized. 
 
46.  The  SPRIP  was  rated successful  in  its  project  completion  report, and  includes  the 
following lessons that have been addressed under the Project.  
(i)  To avoid continued deterioration of roads, time between project preparation and 
implementation has been kept as short as possible. The detailed design of roads 
was completed in January 2009, and procurement was started in March 2009.  
(ii)  Roads to be included in the Project have been selected taking into account local 
network effects, including connection with other classes of roads.  
(iii)  The Government has assured effective and consistent budget allocation and 
expenditure. Coordination with relevant utilities, such as water, electricity, and 
telecommunications, has occurred to avoid unnecessary delays as well as utility 
line work after roadwork is completed.  
(iv)  Environmental clearance for each road has been obtained from the relevant 
authority.  Quarries  for  construction  material  have  been  identified,  and  their 
clearance is being processed.  
(v)  A project performance management system is being designed through close 
consultation and workshops with stakeholders. Surveys had been conducted, 
and additional surveys and further monitoring will occur under the Project.  
(vi)  In cooperation with the Institute for Construction Training and Development, local 
contractors  have  been  trained  on  International  Federation  of  Consulting 
Engineers  conditions  of  contracts,  contract  management,  performance-based 
maintenance  contracts,  and  in  ADB's  procurement  and  consultant  selection 
process.  Further  training  on  construction  planning  and  management  will  be 
provided during implementation.

6.  Government Development Strategy and ADB's Country Strategy 
   
48.  Sri Lanka is on track to achieve the Millennium Development Goal for reducing poverty. 
However, the prolonged conflict have devastated much of the east and north, aggravating the 
already high income and other social differentials between these two regions and the rest of the 
country. The Government’s goal is to achieve high economic growth that benefits the entire 
population and leads to the social development of the entire country. To achieve this, the 
Government’s strategy—entitled Mahinda Chinthana: Vision for a New Sri Lanka – A Ten Year 
Horizon  Development  Framework  2006–201610—focuses  on  strengthening  the  investment 
climate, including road network improvement and socially inclusive and regionally balanced 
growth. 
 
 49.  ADB’s country partnership strategy (CPS) 2009–2011 recognizes that achieving high 
and equitable growth will be vital to reduce poverty further. One key obstacle to growth is a 
serious  infrastructure  bottleneck,  especially  in  the  current  transport  network  that  provides 
inadequate connectivity between global and domestic markets as well as between hinterland 
and economic centers.  
 
50.  The Project will improve connectivity in the transport networks of two relatively poor and 
conflict-affected provinces. The provision of improved roads—in conjunction with a range of 
other  carefully  coordinated  measures  proposed  in  the  CPS,  designed  to  strengthen 
administrative and absorptive capacity in poorer regions—will contribute to poverty reduction. 
The  Project  will  improve  connectivity  to  neglected  areas,  supporting  socially  inclusive 
development, and reduce disparities in Sri Lanka; therefore, the Project is relevant to achieving 
the objective of the CPS.

A.  Impact and Outcome 
51.  In support of the CPS, the project impact will be an overall improvement of Sri Lanka’s 
transport system. Transport of goods and services will be enhanced, contributing to economic 
growth and community well being. The Project’s immediate outcome will be the improved road 
network and institutional capacity in Eastern Province and NCP.

B.  Outputs 
52.  Project outputs are 
(i)  approximately  370  km  of  provincial  roads  rehabilitated  and  improved,  and 
selected bridge links rehabilitated or replaced; 
(ii)  enhanced project management capability of EPRDD and NCPRDA, achieving

(iii)  an improved EPRDD office. 
 
53.  Road Rehabilitation. About 150 km of roads in Eastern Province and 220 km of roads 
in NCP will be rehabilitated.11 The use of the existing road corridor will be maximized to achieve 
the optimal combination of economy and desired road improvement without land acquisition. 
Double  bituminous  surface  treatment  will  be  applied.  Bridges  and  culverts  will  also  be 
rehabilitated and replaced. The technical approach and design standard of the roads are in 
Appendix 4, and the list of contract packages is in Appendix 5. 
 
54.  The roads were selected from the long-list proposed by both provinces. The criteria for 
short-listing the roads included the role of the road in connecting economic and social services 
and national highways, traffic volume, road conditions, poverty index, and the importance of 
road to bus services. A feasibility study was then conducted, considering (i) engineering and 
traffic aspects, (ii) treatment options and cost estimates, (iii) social and environmental aspects, 
and (iv) economic internal rate of returns. The final list of roads then was validated in terms of 
distribution fairness among different ethnic groups. 
 
55.  Project Management. The Project will provide project implementation consultants and 
finance incremental expenditures for successful project implementation. The consultants will 
provide on-the-job training with extensive hands-on technical and managerial skills to provincial 
road agency staff in project and contract management. 
 
56.  EPRDD Office Improvement. While a capacity development TA will be provided to 
strengthen the capacity of the provincial road agencies in managing the provincial road network, 
upgrading the EPRDD office and relevant equipment will be required and will be provided for 
under the loan.  
 
C.  Special Features 
57.  Devolution Process Support. Devolution of power in line with the 13th Amendment to 
the Constitution is an important milestone in achieving a long-term solution of the conflict. The 
institutional and legal aspects related to devolution are assessed in Supplementary Appendix B. 
The  Project  will  support  this  devolution  process  by  improving  provincial  capacity  and  by 
strengthening provincial ownership of road network management. Toward institutional capacity, 
a capacity development TA will be provided to strengthen provincial road agencies to carry out 
their main responsibility—managing and maintaining the provincial road network efficiently and 
economically.  EPRDD's  organizational  effectiveness  will  be  enhanced  by  improving  its 
management structure, streamlining staff allocation, and modernizing basic office facilities and 
the management information system. EPRDD and NCPRDA's capacity for sustainable road 
asset management will be improved by developing and implementing systematic steps for 
monitoring, planning, and programming procedures.

58.  To increase ownership, more responsibilities of project preparation and implementation

59.  Conflict Sensitivity. In line with the key operational guidelines provided in the CPS on 
working in conflict-affected areas, the Project has been prepared emphasizing transparency and 
involving stakeholders and beneficiaries. A conflict awareness assessment was carried out 
(Appendix 6). As an integral part of the Government’s Eastern Revival Plan,12 the Project seems 
to be universally welcome and viewed positively, and it is not perceived to benefit any one group 
at the expense of others. As the Project is intended to improve existing roads (and is creating no 
new roads), it is expected that there will be no resettlement issues, and no land will be claimed 
for the purposes of the Project.  
 
60.  Collaboration among Development Partners. Under the ADB-funded Road Project 
Preparatory Facility, a feasibility study and detailed design for all nine provinces’ provincial 
roads were prepared. In parallel, the three partners ADB, JICA, and the World Bank have 
agreed to support the Government's objective to develop the road network. A joint review during 
project implementation will be explored. 
 
61.  In Eastern Province, ADB, JICA, and the World Bank assistance will cover the whole 
province, benefitting all ethnic groups (Muslim, Sinhalese, and Tamil). The improved provincial 
roads will be connected to local roads financed by JICA; moreover, while ADB will provide TA 
for strengthening EPRDD’s capacity in road asset management and procurement, the World 
Bank will strengthen capacity in safeguard matters, and JICA will provide training in road 
construction  works  to  Eastern  Province  laborers,  who  will  then  be  ready  to  be  hired  by 
contractors.13 Under the Project, civil works were packaged so they could be implemented by 
both local and national contractors, providing employment opportunities to local laborers during 
implementation. All contracts will be implemented in two phases, with relatively a short gap, so 
that they will benefit all communities simultaneously.

2.  Implementation Period 
71.  The  Project  will  be  implemented  in  about  4  years,  reflecting  the  time  required  for 
capacity building within the IAs and among the national contractors, with support from the 
project implementation consultants. Procurement of civil works will be done in two phases. It is 
expected that the Project could be declared effective in October 2009, and will be completed by 
31 December 2013. A detailed project implementation schedule is in Appendix 9. 
 
3.  Procurement 
72.  All  procurement  under  the  loan  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines. Supply contracts will be procured under national competitive bidding 
procedures if the contract values are $100,000–$1,000,000; and shopping if less than $100,000.  
 
73.  As  requested  by  the  Government,  for  civil  works,  national  competitive  bidding 
procedures acceptable to ADB have been adopted. Post-qualification has been exercised for 
civil works contracts, with a bid period of 30 days, applying a single-stage two-envelope bidding 
procedure. The use of these procedures is justified as the Project is located in a conflict-affected 
area, where foreign contractors are not likely to be interested in bidding. The works are simple 
and can be carried out by domestic contractors. The previous two projects (RSDP and SPRIP) 
also  adopted  national  competitive  bidding  for  all  civil  works,  and  both  were  successfully 
implemented without significant delay.  
 
74.  The road and bridge civil works will be undertaken in 26 contract packages, ranging from 
$0.2 million to $3.4 million, and building works of two contract packages, valued at about $0.4 
million each. Civil works are packaged based on their geographical location and convenience 
for  contractors  to  mobilize  and  organize,  and  will  be  implemented  in  two  phases.  The 
procurement plan is in Appendix 10. 
 
4.  Consulting Services 
75.  Consultants will be recruited in line with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). IAs, assisted by MLGPC, will hire consulting teams as 
project implementation consultants separately, which will assume the role of the engineer for the 
civil works contracts, respectively. The consultants will support IAs in implementing the Project, 
and strengthen IAs' capacity in contract management, project performance monitoring, and 
evaluation. Consultants will be selected using quality- and cost-based selection procedures, 
with a 90:10 proportion of quality to cost. About 70 person-months of international consultants 
and 1,514 person-months of national consultants will be required. The outline terms of reference 
for the consultants are in Supplementary Appendix C.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
91.  Overall, the Project will contribute to the improvement of the road sector in Eastern 
Province  and  NCP  by  improving  transport  efficiency  and  expanding  access  to  economic 
opportunities and public services. The beneficiaries will be people, companies, government 
agencies, and nongovernment agencies that use project road transport services directly and 
indirectly. Communities served by the project roads will benefit from improved, lower-cost, and

social  services.  Transport  operators  carrying both  passengers  and  freight  will  benefit  from 
improved roads in terms of lower vehicle-operating costs, time-savings, improved road safety, 
and thereby, increased productivity. Government and nongovernment agencies served by the 
project roads will improve their service delivery due to improved transport efficiency. 
 
A.  Technical Aspect 
92.  The Project will improve about 14% of the provincial road network in Eastern Province 
and 11% in NCP. Road asset management and maintenance will be strengthened. As the 
Government relies heavily on external financing for road rehabilitation and reconstruction, the 
Project will have significant impact in the provincial road network in both provinces.  
 
B.  Institutional Aspect 
93.  The  Project  will  improve  management  of  the  provincial  road  network  through  an 
institutional development program, assisted by the capacity development TA. The enhancement 
of  the  provincial  road  agencies’  capacity  for  road  asset  management  will  improve  road 
administration  governance  and  accountability,  and  create  an  environment  that  encourages 
efficiency and competition. 
 
C.  Economic Aspect 
94.  The overall improvement of the provincial road network will increase transport efficiency. 
This will contribute to growth of a wide range of economic activities that use road transport 
services. Without the improvements, traffic will incur high transport operating costs due to poor 
road conditions. With the improvements, these costs will be reduced. 
 
95.  An economic analysis was carried out using the standard practice, comparing the road 
lifecycle and user costs with and without the Project. Based on the analysis, the proposed 
improvements were considered economically viable, with an estimated overall economic internal 
rate of return of 28.3%. A sensitivity analysis was also carried out considering the potential 
adverse  scenario—increasing  project  costs  and  reducing  benefits.  The  resulting  economic 
internal rates of return remained above the 12% threshold. The summary of economic analysis 
is in Supplementary Appendix E. 
 
96.  The financial internal rate of return calculation was not required as the Project does not 
generate  revenue.  Public  expenditure  review  of  provincial  roads  in  both  provinces  was 
completed (Supplementary Appendix F). Assessments were carried out with regard to EPRDD 
and NCPRDA's capacity in planning, budgeting, internal control and audit arrangements, as well 
as financial management and reporting management. Both follow the government accounting 
standard and general accounting principals. They have the financial management capacity to 
effectively implement the Project. 
 
D.  Environmental Aspect 
97.  The Project is a class B project in accordance with ADB environmental assessment 
requirements.  Initial  environmental  examinations  were  prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
Environment Policy (2002) and environmental guidelines. No significant adverse environmental 
impacts are expected. The project road improvement proposals have been approved by the 
Central  Environmental  Authority,  and  its  recommendations  have  been  incorporated  in  the

environmental  management  plan  as  well  as  bidding  documents.  The  summary  initial 
environmental examinations are in Supplementary Appendix G. 
 
E.  Social Aspect 
98.  The inadequate condition of transport services prevents the poor from gaining access to 
economic opportunities and social services. The Project will improve the road network, thereby 
alleviating  this  constraint.  The  project  roads  serve  the  poorest  provinces  in  the  country—
communities located away from the centers of economic activities. Improvement of the road 
network will open the communities up to a range of new opportunities; increase availability and 
frequency of transport service; and improve access to markets, employment opportunities, and 
social services. They will facilitate movement of goods and people, and will improve livelihood 
activities of the communities along the roads, including returned internally displaced people. 
 
99.  From experience of a previous project (SPRIP), road improvements will lead to more 
frequent and reliable bus services, and all passengers benefit from reduced travel time. Faster 
travel, at lower cost, allows workers to find better work opportunities and to earn more (e.g., 
through overtime). Both producers and consumers of agricultural produce will also benefit from 
improved freight services. 
 
100.  The roads included in the Project were selected upon consideration of their role in 
providing connectivity to communities, the poverty situation, and coverage of transport services. 
Each road plays a significant role by connecting to local feeder roads, resulting in a wider 
spread of indirect benefits. The benefits are not confined to any specific ethnic or other social 
group. Local laborers will have employment opportunities during implementation. 
 
101.  No new roads will be developed, and the road improvement work is within the existing  
right-of-way. Nevertheless, in the event of unforeseen requirement of land acquisition during 
implementation, resettlement plans will be prepared following the relevant national laws as well 
as ADB's Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995), in accordance with the approved resettlement 
framework (Appendix 13).  
 
102.  A grievances redress committee will be established within each divisional secretary, 
chaired by the respective divisional secretary, chief engineer, community-level mediation board, 
and community leader. The aim is to resolve issues quickly, amicably, transparently, and out of 
courts to facilitate project implementation. The resident engineers of the project implementation 
consultants  will  maintain  a  complaint  register  and  forward  these  to  the  grievance  redress 
committee. The details of the grievances and the reasons that led to acceptance or rejection of 
the particular grievances will be recorded. 
 
103.  The  summary  poverty  reduction  and  social  strategy  is  in  Appendix  14.  To  enable 
communities in the project area to maximize benefits of the Project, a proposal for promoting 
gender-responsive access to road rehabilitation-related opportunities under the Project is being 
developed, to be financed on grant basis from the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction.  
 
F.  Risks 
104.  The major risks for the Project are (i) implementation delays, (ii) delay in releasing 
counterpart funds, (iii) inadequate post-project road maintenance, and (iv) conflict. The risk of 
initial delays has been mitigated through ensuring project implementation readiness during 
processing.  Feasibility  study,  detailed  design,  and  procurement  assistance  were  provided

through the TA loan for the Road Project Preparatory Facility. Advance actions are being taken 
with the objective of awarding contracts immediately following the loan signing. The risk of delay 
in releasing counterpart funds has been mitigated by providing 90% financing under the loan, 
leaving the Government with financing only tax and duties.  
 
105.  Performance-based maintenance after completion will be included in the civil works 
contracts to secure maintenance of the project roads. Through the capacity development TA 
project,  EPRDD  and  NCPRDA  road  asset  management  systems  will  be  strengthened  for 
objective planning and budgeting. A 3-year rolling road maintenance plan will be developed. 
Vehicle license fee revenues will be dedicated to routine maintenance. Budgets will be gradually 
increased to meet maintenance requirements, and EPRDD and NCPRDA's monitoring systems 
for implementation will minimize the risk of underutilizing these budgets. 
 
106.  There are general risks associated with communal tension and sensitivities, history, 
political uncertainty, return of displaced persons, and considerable security staff presence. Also, 
an unforeseen requirement of land acquisition may emerge during implementation, for which a 
resettlement plan will then need to be prepared. The Project is not expected to contribute to 
social  tensions,  as  the  beneficial  outcomes  of  the  Project—with  the  JICA-  and  World  
Bank-financed projects—are shared equitably among the major ethnic groups and across the 
target area. The Project can potentially make a positive contribution to the rebuilding of the 
infrastructure in post-conflict-affected areas. 
 
107.  On security, because the east and north have been taken over fully by the Government, 
a  serious  threat  is  less  likely.  While  it  is  possible  that  some  events  could  affect  project 
implementation, it is highly unlikely that there will be any direct threats to the Project. All 
communities are likely to see the Project as part of the overall improvement of living conditions 
and the creation of new livelihood opportunities.

EASTERN AND NORTH CENTRAL PROVINCIAL ROADS: SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Eastern Province 
1.  Eastern Province, along the eastern seaboard of Sri Lanka, has three administrative 
districts,  i.e.,  Ampara,  Batticaloa,  and  Trincomalee.  Trincomalee  has  a  natural  deepwater 
harbour, the fifth largest in the world. However, it has been developed only for flour processing, 
cement manufacture, and oil storage facilities. The beaches of Eastern Province are popular 
with tourists, but current limited access constrains tourism development. The economy relies 
mainly on agriculture, animal husbandry, and fisheries.   
2.  The  province  had  an  estimated  population  of  1.46  million  in  2007.  Life  in  Eastern 
Province has been subject to disruptions due to intermittent armed conflicts in the area over the 
last two decades. Due to the conflict situation, the province was not included in the last poverty 
study, however, poverty in the province is among the worst in the country. Per capita income in 
2007 for the province was SLRs119,131 per year, or 66.6% of national per capita income. While 
the area represents 15% area of the country, its gross domestic product (GDP) in 2007 was 
SLRs177,863, or 4.97% of the national GDP. 
 
1.  Provincial Road Network and Traffic Volume 
3.  The  province’s  road  network  includes  857  kilometers  (km)  of  national  highways,  
1,098 km of provincial roads, 4,838 km of rural roads, and 3,412 km of other roads. The road 
density is 1.02 km/square kilometre (km2), while the national road density is 1.5 km/km2. About 
30% of provincial roads are gravel and earth; only 20% are in good condition. About 65% are in 
poor  or  very  poor  condition,  requiring  rehabilitation  and  reconstruction.  Where  access  is 
possible, riding conditions are poor, vehicle speeds low, and vehicle-operating costs high.  
4.  In 2007, the estimated fleet of motorized vehicles in Eastern Province was 92,091; this 
accounted for 4.1% of the total fleet in Sri Lanka. From 2003 to 2007, the vehicle fleet in the 
province increased at an average annual growth rate of 8.5%. However this growth was mostly 
due to motorcycles and three-wheelers. The typical average speed on the provincial road 
network is 10 km/hour. 
 
2.  Provincial Road Asset Management 
5.  The Eastern Provincial Road Development Department (EPRDD) is responsible for the 
construction, maintenance, and administration of the provincial road network. It is headed by a 
provincial director who works directly under the authority of the province's secretary of road 
development. The provincial director is assisted by a deputy director, four chief engineers, a 
chief accountant, an administrative officer, and other support staff. Four executive engineers 
report to the respective chief engineer in the three districts. 
6.  EPRDD’s  capacity  for  core  processes  requires  strengthening  and  reorganizing, 
especially in the areas of policy making, planning, and programming. It has not developed a 
proper mechanism for regular road condition assessment, which is required to develop annual 
development and budgetary plans. The road conditions were assessed based on information 
provided by EPRDD field officers and complaints made by the public. Only a road inventory is 
currently available.

SUMMARY OF DESIGN STANDARD AND TECHNICAL APPROACH 
 
 
A.  Design Criteria 
1.  Design Standards and Guidelines. The Project consists of class C and D roads within 
the provincial road network. The following design standards and guidelines, established in 
consultation with the Road Development Authority (RDA) and provincial road agency officials, 
are applied: 
 
(i)  Cross section: (a) Road Design Manual and Bridge Design Manual—RDA's 
standard; (b) AASHTO—Geometric Design of Highways and Streets 5th edition 
(2004); (c) TRL—Overseas Road Note 6, A Guide to Geometric Design (1988), 
and (d) Austroads—Rural Road Design (2003). 
 
(ii)  Bridges: RDA's Sri Lanka Bridge Design Manual of 1997, based on the British 
Standards Code of Practice for Bridge Design (BS5400:1990). 
 
(iii)  Pavement:  (a)  Transport  Research  Laboratory’s  Road  Note  31,  4th  Edition 
(TRL-RN31), basis of RDA's pavement design process;  (b) AASHTO Pavement 
Design Guide, and (c) design life for new pavements: 10-year life with provision 
for overlays during or at the end of that period to extend the life to 15–20 years. 
 
(iv)  Drainage: RDA's standards incorporating relevant standards from AASHTO and 
the British Standard Design Manual for Roads and Bridges. 
 
2.  Pavement Treatment. Existing road pavement consists of either bituminous surface or 
unsealed gravel. Many roads have mixed sections of bituminous and gravel. Some sections of 
bituminous  pavements  have  deteriorated  as  gravel.  Double  bituminous  surface  treatment 
(DBST) will be applied to all projects roads. 
 
3.  Cross  Section.  Road  cross  sections  vary  depending  on  projected  traffic  volume, 
geometric  condition,  and  terrain.  In  general,  the  cross  section  consists  of  carriageway  
4.5–6.5  meters  (m),  shoulder  1.0–1.5  m  each  side,  with  drainage  and  berm  as  required. 
Sidewalks (typically 1.2 m wide) for bridges are considered on a case-by-case basis, depending 
on bridge length, location, and pedestrian and traffic volume. Use of the existing road corridor 
(existing road cross section and provision for utilities) is maximized to achieve the optimal 
combination of economy and desired road improvement without land acquisition. 
 
4.  Alignment and Traffic Facilities. In general, the proposed improvements follow the 
existing horizontal and vertical alignment. The only minor changes are applied to the horizontal 
alignment for very short sections to enhance road safety, to ease the radius of curves, or 
minimize blind spots. The road safety aspects relate mostly to localized sections of the road 
alignments. In densely populated areas, roads, bridges, and associated sidewalks are made 
accessible for all, including the disabled. 
 
5.  Road Safety. The road safety aspects are related mostly to localized sections of the 
alignments. Based on the road safety inspections, carried out on all roads during the field 
evaluation, the detailed design, wherever possible, incorporates improvements to road width 
and alignment, including installing precautionary speed signs to slow down for oncoming curves 
or low speed areas.

6.  Drainage. To minimize local flooding or ponding, side drains are reconstructed to direct 
surface flows away from road pavements and linked to streams or watercourses. For existing 
drainage structures (retained or repaired), the waterways are restored by removing settled 
materials and debris.  
 
7.  Bridges. Improvements comprise repairing and or replacing existing bridge structures, 
including  structural  renovation  of  substructure  and  superstructure  elements  together  with 
installation or repair of guardrails and improvement of causeways and vented drifts. The work

CONFLICT AWARENESS ASSESSMENT 
 
1.  The Project, aiming to improve provincial roads, is an integral part of the Government’s 
Mahinda  Chinthana  (nationally)  and  Eastern  Revival  plan  for  Eastern  Province.  Road 
improvements in Eastern Province and its adjacent North Central Province (NCP) are badly 
needed to support economic and social development. Such infrastructure improvements also 
appear to be welcomed by all communities in both provinces, as long as they are perceived to 
be equitably distributed geographically and benefit all communities (both in terms of generating 
employment and facilitating commerce and access to markets and services). The project team 
has engaged in several consultations to ensure stakeholder participation and acceptance. While 
under  the  Project,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  finance  the  improvement  of 
provincial roads in two districts of Eastern Province, namely Batticaloa and Trincomalee, the 
World Bank will cover Ampara, the remaining district. More broadly, nationally, the Project is 
closely coordinated with similar projects of both the World Bank and the Japan International 
Cooperation  Agency  to  ensure  national  conflict  sensitivity  of  overall  provincial  road 
improvement. 
 
A.  Background 
 
2.  Eastern Province experienced some of the worst violence in Sri Lanka’s decades-long 
conflict, although the situation in the province has stabilized since the Sri Lankan Government 
liberated the east from control by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) in July 2007. Sri 
Lanka’s Eastern Province is unique in its demographics: Tamils account for about 40% of the 
total population, Moslems account for 38%, and Sinhalese about 22%. However, the balance 
between  the  three  communities  varies  significantly  over  Eastern  Province’s  three  districts: 
Trincomalee (46% Moslem, 29% Tamil, 25% Sinhalese), Batticaloa (25% Moslem, 75% Tamil, 
less than 1% Sinhalese), and Ampara (44% Moslem, 18% Tamil, 37% Sinhalese). 
 
3.  Elections to the Eastern Provincial Council were held on 10 May 2008, and the first 
session  of  the  Eastern  Provincial  Council  took  place  in  Trincomalee  on  4  June  2008. 
Development  in  Eastern  Province  is  a  high  priority  for  the  national  Government.  The 
Government’s 3-year Eastern Revival development plan focuses on resettlement of internally 
displaced persons, revitalizing the regional economy, improving infrastructure, supporting social 
rehabilitation and improved housing, and rebuilding public institutions. The plan is seen as 
critical to the long-term stability of the province (and, indeed, of the country as a whole), to gain 
support of the Tamil and Moslem communities who form a majority in the region, and to prevent 
a return to armed conflict. While much activity is under way to develop the economy and rebuild 
the infrastructure of Eastern Province, reconciliation among the communities in this post-conflict 
period will inevitably require time. 
 
4.  In NCP, the population is more than 90% Sinhalese, less than 2% Tamil, and 5%–10% 
Moslem. NCP has experienced sporadic violence over the years, mainly because it borders 
Northern and Eastern Provinces, which have been the main focus of the conflict with the LTTE. 
For  the  past  two  decades,  development  in  NCP  has  been  constrained  by  the  province’s 
proximity to the conflict. 
 
5.  The Project is consistent with ADB’s country partnership strategy and conflict sensitivity 
guidelines. Nationally, it balances development in conflict-affected regions with development in 
other  parts  of  the  country,  both  directly  through  ADB-supported  activities  and  through 
coordination with the support of other key development partners. Secondly, ADB has taken 
steps to ensure equity in the spread of benefits and opportunities created by the Project (across

both communal and geographic lines). ADB has coordinated provincial road improvement plans 
with those of the World Bank and the Japan International Cooperation Agency to ensure wider 
coverage of such improvements. Also, ADB has coordinated with other development partners in 
complementary  training  and  capacity-building  activities  to  strengthen  road  agencies  and 
contractors, as well as develop skills to assist local labor to participate actively in project 
implementation. 
 
B.  Security Situation 
 
6.  Government plans to normalize security in the province are under way, and the number 
of military- and police-based checkpoints in Trincomalee and Batticaloa is being reduced. The 
presence of security in the provinces is expected to decrease over time, especially following the 
recent military victory over the LTTE in the north. This will positively affect commerce and 
economic development in Eastern Province. While the presence of paramilitary groups has 
been a cause of concern and tension in Eastern Province, the Government is moving ahead 
with plans to disarm and/or integrate armed groups into the police and military. 
 
7.  People seem to be relieved that the situation is relatively stable, but uncertainty (and, 
therefore, apprehension) about the future remains. Some of the underlying factors causing 
tensions in Eastern Province are still present, however, the trend on the security front has been 
positive.  
 
8.  The scenarios for the near future of Eastern Province are varied, and, while some events 
could affect project implementation at some point, direct threats to the Project are not likely. All 
communities are likely to see the Project as part of the overall improvement of living conditions 
and the creation of new livelihood opportunities. 
 
9.  As the security situation in the Northern Province normalizes, when the A9 (the main 
north–south highway) is fully opened, and as development plans move steadily forward in the 
north, then NCP should benefit. 
 
C.  Project Context 
 
10.  Because the Project is intended to improve existing provincial roads (and is creating no 
new ones), it does not involve any resettlement issues; and no land is to be claimed for it. This 
is important as land issues have often been a key factor behind the conflict. 
 
11.  The roads to be improved are based on a list submitted to ADB by NCP and Eastern 
Province. In the case of Eastern Province, the selection of roads and the rationale and criteria 
used in their selection was discussed with the Provincial Council following its election. 
 
12.  While disputes over issues such as land and water surrounding some development 
projects in Eastern Province have led to tensions between communities, road development 
projects  seem  to  be  universally  welcome  and  viewed  positively,  as  long  as  they  are  not 
perceived to benefit any one group at the expense of others. 
 
13.  As the Project is implemented, ADB will be mindful of equity in the schedule on which 
improvements  are  made.  The  Project  has  been  designed  in  ways  that  will  benefit  all 
communities reasonably equally (or at least will not favor some at the perceived expense of 
others), but the implementation is another dimension of the Project that ADB will monitor.

D.  Conclusion 
 
14.  Eastern Province is the most complex region of Sri Lanka, with a history of communal 
tension, violence, displacement (and return of internally displaced people), and land disputes. At 
present, any development partner should be aware of the general risks associated with historic 
tensions. Conflict sensitivity considerations are essential for projects in Eastern Province in this 
post-conflict  period.  However,  road  projects,  as  long  as  they  are  implemented  with  an 
awareness of the prevailing sensitivities among the communities, are not likely to be a great risk 
(certainly less so than projects in some other sectors). Furthermore, the economic situation in 
NCP is likely to improve, and better provincial roads will be a significant factor.

RESETTLEMENT FRAMEWORK 
 
A.  Project Background 
 
1.  The Project consists of the rehabilitation of about 370 kilometers (km) of provincial roads 
in  Eastern  Province  (Batticaloa  and  Trincomalee  districts)  and  North  Central  Province 
(Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa districts), and the rehabilitation or replacement of 33 minor 
bridges. The Project is designed to use only the existing right-of-way (ROW), about 7–8 meters. 
All rehabilitation components related to roads and bridges such as the carriage way, pavement, 
and drainage facilities will be within the existing ROW. The consultant engineers and engineers 
of provincial road agencies of each province jointly conducted field assessments to determine 
road rehabilitation needs and possible permanent and temporary land acquisition and other 
resettlement  impacts  of  selected  roads.  The  assessment  process  involved  measuring  the 
existing  ROW  and  pavement  widths;  identifying  existing  drainage  deficiencies;  taking 
photographs; and measuring bridge dimensions including span length, deck width, and water 
level at bridge sites. In the absence of recent land survey drawings and maps prepared by the 
provincial road agency or survey department indicating the existing ROW and road boundaries 
for  each  road,  consultant  engineers  and  the  staff  of  provincial  road  agencies  determined 
whether the existing road corridor of each road is adequate to meet rehabilitation requirements 
of  selected  roads  and  bridges.  In  the  case  of  bridges,  the  Project  will  not  increase  the 
carriageway width. However, some bridges that are unsafe and cannot be repaired will be 
replaced with new bridges. Based on the information available from the engineers' assessments 
and  using  their  guidance,  resettlement  specialists  carried  out  sample  surveys,  rapid 
assessments based on field observations, walk-through surveys and discussions with local 
affected people. 
 
2.  Although  the  project  feasibility  study  (July  2008)  and  detailed  engineering  study 
(February 2009) indicate that no land acquisition is required for the purposes of the Project, 
exact actual permanent and temporary impacts from the rehabilitation works will be known only 
during project implementation. The rehabilitation works could have some impacts on lands and 
buildings  adjacent  to  the  boundary  walls,  drainages,  and  canals.  Moreover,  some  land 
acquisition might be required for the construction of new bridges. The common feature of rural 
roads is that pavements, shoulders, and side drains are very narrow or nonexistent in some 
road sections so that the implementing agencies may decide to acquire minimum land for 
proper rehabilitation works. Services relocation such as shifting of telephone and electricity 
transmission lines may require land acquisition. Some road sections in semi-urban and urban 
areas may require widening and realignment to ensure road safety and smooth traffic flow. In 
such cases, the project implementing agencies will formulate short resettlement plans and 
submit  them  to  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  for  review  and  approval  before  any 
construction work in the road section is started. The potential number of households or the land 
area acquired in such a situation would be small based on field assessments.  
 
3.   This  resettlement  framework  was  formulated  to  ensure  that  if  land  acquisition 
(permanent or temporary), physical relocation, and other impacts are identified during project 
implementation,  appropriate  compensation  and  relocation  programs  will  be  prepared  and 
implemented to meet Sri Lankan laws, National Involuntary Resettlement Policy (2001), and 
ADB's Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995) requirement.

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Link to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
Sri Lanka is on track to achieve the Millennium Development Goal for reducing poverty. However, conflicts that 
began in 1983 and the tsunami in 2004 have devastated much of the north and east of the country. This has 
aggravated the already high income and other social indicator differentials between these two regions and the 
rest of the country. The goal of the Government’s national development plan is to achieve high economic growth 
that benefits the entire population and leads to the social development of the country. To achieve this goal, the 
Government’s  strategy.  Mahinda  Chinthana–Sri  Lanka  (adopted  in  2007)  focuses  on  (i)  strengthening  the 
investment  climate,  and  (ii)  achieving  socially  inclusive  and  regionally  balanced  growth.  ADB’s  country 
partnership strategy 2009–2011 recognizes that achieving high and equitable growth will be vital to reduce 
poverty further. One of the key obstacles to growth that the country partnership strategy identifies is a serious 
infrastructure bottleneck, especially the current transport network that does not provide adequate connectivity 
between global and domestic markets.  
The Project will improve connectivity in the transport networks of two relatively poor and conflict-affected 
provinces: Eastern Province and North Central Province (NCP). The provision of improved roads—in conjunction 
with a range of other carefully coordinated measures proposed in the country partnership strategy and designed 
to strengthen administrative and absorptive capacity in the poorer regions—will contribute to poverty reduction by 
encouraging farmers to diversify their incomes by selling higher-value products or providing labor in nearby 
markets. Road network improvements will increase agricultural productivity by improving the supply of key inputs 
such as seeds, fertilizers, and technical services. By reducing local travel costs and travel times, the Project will 
facilitate regular and timely attendance at schools, faster and more regular access to health centers, as well as 
easier access to local government departments and other service providers, thereby further stimulating the kinds 
of investments that will strengthen regional development. 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
1.  Key Issues. In 2006, Sri Lanka ranked 104th of 179 countries according to the United Nations' human 
development index (HDI). Similarly, of the 157 countries with both HDI and gender-related development index 
values, Sri Lanka ranks 92nd.a The national poverty incidence in Sri Lanka has remained static at around 22% 
since the 1990s. Poverty reduction has been slow during the past decade and uneven across sectors—rapid in 
the urban sector, but slow or stagnant in rural and estate sectors. Poverty in rural areas is consistently higher 
than in urban areas, and national development-related achievements often conceal large discrepancies between 
individual districts and/or provinces. About 5% of the total project beneficiary population is urban, while the 
remaining 95% is rural. 
Climatic and agroecological conditions are more or less similar in both Eastern Province and NCP. Both regions 
depend on the northeast monsoons (November to February) for water, and experience prolonged periods of 
drought during the summer months. This has led to the development of agriculture-based livelihood systems that 
combine both irrigated and rain-fed paddy cultivation with "chena" farming (slash-and-burn or shifting cultivation) 
marked by the annual planting of coarse grains, legumes, oilseeds, and vegetables. More that 200,000 of Sri 
Lanka’s poorest families depend on chena cultivation for subsistence. Every year, if and when the rains come, 
crops and vegetables flood the market at the same time causing prices to drop.  
The causes of poverty in Sri Lanka are complex and interlinked. The probability of being poor decreases with 
market  integration,  educational  attainment,  and  the  availability  and  quality  of  basic  infrastructure  such  as 
electricity, roads, and water and sanitation. The poverty head count index among influential areas of candidate 
roads in NCP ranges from 14 to 31. In Eastern Province, the poverty head count index ranges from 17 to 46.

The Project's main pro-poor design feature is the devolution of management responsibilities to the provincial

Other features include specific clauses in the contract documents to encourage civil works contractors to employ

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis 
Key Issues. Due to the long prevailing conflict in Sri Lanka, the livelihoods of people in much of the north and 
east of the country have been devastated. These regions, especially Eastern Province, were also affected by the 
tsunami that ravaged so much of coastal South and Southeast Asia in December 2004. Although the north and 
east combined made up about 14% of the population on the island in 2003, the regional economy contributed 
only 8% of national gross domestic product. Agriculture and fisheries continue to make up a significant part of the 
economy, but the importance of the sector has eroded during the conflict years. Before the conflict, paddy, 
onions, chilies, tobacco, fruits, dairy products, and fish were sold in significant quantities to other parts of the 
country. However, due to transportation difficulties and the trade embargo, commercial agriculture throughout 
much of the region was transformed into subsistence agriculture.  
Eastern Province roads in particular are seriously dilapidated. No rehabilitation and little maintenance have been 
carried out for the last decade or more. This seriously impedes efforts to reduce poverty along with other 
development interventions planned for the region. However, with provincial elections in Eastern Province having 
gone ahead as planned on 10 May 2008, the prospect of political stability and development is enhanced there 
and in neighboring regions. Trincomalee is the capital of Eastern Province and one of the foremost regional 
centers in Sri Lanka. It has an important natural harbor and deep-water port connecting Sri Lanka with the 
outside world. Anuradhapura is the administrative capital of NCP. Many industries such as paddy processing 
mills, concrete workshops, hotels, shops, and vehicle service stations are located along the project roads in its 
vicinity.
